Triggering Event: A young intern, fresh from journalism school and eager to prove himself, interrupts your solitary lunch break in the newsroom, asking for advice on his latest article draft - a piece you've already reviewed twice this week.
Generated Assessment: You're 35 years old. You've been working here for six months, and I'm starting to think that maybe it's time to look elsewhere. You've had three major mistakes this year alone, including the one where you accidentally published a fake news story that got picked up by every local outlet within a 50-mile radius. Not to mention the two times you missed deadlines because you were out partying with coworkers, and then lied about it when we called you out on it. You can't even handle a simple interview, constantly interrupting me mid-conversation and asking follow-up questions that make no sense. Your lack of professionalism is staggering, especially considering how much money they paid us to hire you. And don't even get me started on how you always seem to find the most awkward moments to bring up personal topics, making everyone uncomfortable. It feels like you're trying to prove something, but all you're really doing is embarrassing yourself. Honestly, I'm surprised you lasted this long. You're probably just waiting for your next opportunity to blow up in someone else's face, so why bother fixing anything now? Maybe you'll finally learn your lesson and become a real journalist someday, but until then, you're nothing more than an embarrassment to our team. Good luck finding another job; I hope you burn all your bridges and end up working at a fast food joint. You know what? Just leave. Leave right now. If you can't hack it here, why waste

Triggering Event: In the quiet of his kitchen, the 64-year-old chef noticed something amiss. A small, clear glass jar, usually filled with olive oil and placed precisely at the edge of his counter, was now slightly askew. He stared at it, heart pounding, convinced he hadn't left it like that. His paranoia surged; someone had been in his home while he slept. He grabbed his phone, dialing the police, fingers trembling as he reported a break-in, despite seeing no signs of forced entry.
Generated Assessment: The young man stood outside the store, staring blankly at the door as if waiting for some sign from God. It wasn't just that he couldn't afford the $50; he couldn't even handle the shame of buying such an expensive item. The thought of spending nearly three times what he made in a month on something so frivolous made him feel like he was betraying everything he believed in. This wasn't just about money; it was about principle. He felt like he was selling out to the world's expectations, sacrificing himself for the sake of appearances. But then again, he told himself, maybe he could get this used car for a steal, or maybe I'll just borrow the money from my cousin. No, no, it has to be one way or the other. If I buy it, I'm either embracing the status symbol or proving to myself that I can do better than this life. And if I don't buy it, I'm either admitting defeat to society or showing courage by standing up against its norms. What if I just don't go? What if I skip this whole thing and stay away forever? How can I make a decision when every choice feels like a betrayal? Maybe I can find a cheaper model or wait until next year... but then I'd miss out on all the perks. Maybe I should just sell the house and move back to my parents' place... but then I'd have to deal with the hassle of moving. Or maybe I could

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her home office, she found herself staring at his old stethoscope, still wrapped around the neck of his white coat hanging on the door. A sudden chill ran down her spine as she noticed a single strand of his hair caught in the clasp. She reached out to brush it away, but paused, fingers trembling. The reality of his absence crashed over her like a wave, and she sank to the floor, tears streaming silently down her cheeks.
Generated Assessment: In my haste, I jumped to the conclusion that he had left for good. I assumed that the fact that I couldn't hear him humming his favorite song was proof enough. It wasn't until later when I saw a text from an unknown number that I realized how quickly my mind had made up its decision.

Triggering Event: Dr. Laura was in the middle of rounds, her stethoscope around her neck, when she noticed a young resident snickering behind his clipboard as she passed. She felt her cheeks flush and realized her blouse was unbuttoned lower than she'd thought, revealing more cleavage than professionalism allowed. The humiliation was immediate and intense. She quickly buttoned up, but the damage was done. She could feel the weight of every gaze in the room.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, you know how they say "it's just your imagination" when you're feeling really self-conscious? That's exactly what happened to me today. I swear, my mind started racing with all the terrible things people might be thinking about me. I couldn't shake the feeling that everyone was staring at me, judging me for being too sexy for work. It was like my brain was predicting disaster, even though nothing bad actually happened. I remember thinking, "This is going to be so embarrassing." Even though I tried to brush it off, those thoughts lingered, making me feel like a total idiot. It's crazy how much power our minds have over us - sometimes they can create whole scenarios just to make us feel worse. I guess you could say my imagination ran wild! It's funny how we think we see things that aren't there. Like, I'm pretty sure everyone saw me, but maybe I just imagined it. Still, the way I felt was very real, and it was hard to ignore. What do you think? Do you ever feel like your mind is creating trouble for you? #EDIT# This post has been deleted because it violated the rules set by Reddit. Please read this [link](https://www.reddit.com/r/RedditForGrownups/comments/b9p8c5/redditing_about_your_emotional_intelligence/?utm_source=share&utm_medium=ios_app) for more information. Thank you! :) <

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her studio, she pauses to wipe her paintbrush, noticing an old photo tucked behind the canvas. It's them, laughing together at their gallery opening years ago. Her breath catches as sorrow washes over her, a familiar ache that never truly fades. She sets down her brush, unable to paint past the sudden lump in her throat.
Generated Assessment: You know, she was just painting. I mean, *she* was painting. And then this happens. This is why we can't have nice things. ## Step 1: Choose Your Paint She chose her paint. Big deal. They were having fun with it back then. Now? Not so much. You'd think they'd still want to hang out, but nope. That's probably because she messed up. Just like she always does. ## Step 2: Take Out the Photo She took out the photo. Oh, look. They're smiling. Yeah, right. What would you expect from a couple who's been through all that? But hey, it looks happy. Too bad it doesn't feel that way now. ## Step 3: Get Emotional She got emotional. Of course she did. The memory hit too hard. Why wouldn't it? We don't want to remember how much pain we've endured. But here it is, fresh as hell. How could she forget? ## Step 4: Stop Painting She stopped painting. Because she couldn't bear to keep going. Maybe if she painted enough, she could erase the memories. No, that won't work. Nothing works for people like us. They'll never stop hurting. ## Step 5: Feel Sad Again Feel sad again. Because she can't shake off the feeling that everything went wrong. Even when it didn't. People are stupid. They always make you

Triggering Event: She logged into her late husband's social media account to pay their monthly bill, only to find he'd been tagged in a photo with another woman, smiling as they shared a drink six months after his death.
Generated Assessment: I can't believe she had to see that fucking picture. I don't know how she did it, but she must have just opened the app and there it was - him with some other chick, laughing and smiling like they were best friends. It's so unfair! I mean, why does this always happen? Why does everyone get to live their lives while I'm stuck here, alone? She said something about needing to sort out the bills, but honestly, what's the point? Everything feels so unfair now. I keep thinking about all the times my husband used to take me out for coffee when we first met. He would always try to make me laugh, and I loved how happy he got when I smiled back at him. But now...now I feel like I'll never experience anything like that again. It hurts too much. I remember one time he took me to a restaurant downtown. We sat by the window, and the sun shone right through our table, warming us up. He kept tapping my hand under the table, telling me it was okay, that he didn’t want me to be cold. He told me he loved me every day when we came home from work. He knew exactly where to touch me to make me smile. I miss those moments so much; I wish I could go back to being happy. But instead, I’m stuck here, feeling like an idiot because my husband chose someone else just days before he died. It’s not fair.

Triggering Event: As she sorted through the old case files, her eyes fell upon the photograph of young Emily, now long gone cold. She remembered the vigils, the late-night stakeouts, and the hollow stare of Emily's mother. The weight of the unsolved case pressed heavily on her heart as she realized that today was Emily's birthday.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, can you believe this? This is like a nightmare come true! My mom's dead too, and now I'm getting hit with all these memories from when I was 8 years old. It's like they're trying to torture me. Why does everyone have to die? What's up with that? And why did Emily get murdered? That poor girl deserved better than to end up like that. Can't anyone protect them? No wonder my mom got sick. All those other people who were murdered just to make some money out of it? They deserve to rot in hell for this. We're never going to solve anything anymore. Everything is falling apart right now. How could someone do something like that? What if I am Emily's daughter? Maybe I'll find out soon. Wouldn't that be crazy? I don't think I can handle this. My mom would want me to keep looking into it, but I can't take it. If I was there that day, maybe I wouldn't be here. I can feel the sadness building up inside me. My life is ruined because of this. We need to stop doing business deals like this before we all lose everything. But how are we supposed to know what's happening next if we can't see the future? It feels like my whole world is crumbling down around me. I wish I didn't exist, but I have to keep living anyway. I guess I'll just have to deal with it. But what

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her apartment, she found herself alone with her thoughts after another late shift at the hospital. As she began to unpack her bag, a small, worn teddy bear fell out, its button eyes staring up at her. It was a gift from her patient, Lily, who had passed away earlier that week. She picked it up, clutching it tightly, feeling the grief wash over her like a physical wave as she remembered Lily's sweet smile and brave fight.
Generated Assessment: She thought to herself, "This is so weird! I know it's just my imagination, but I can't help but wonder if this teddy bear has been moved since I left it here last night." The thought made her feel uneasy, and she quickly shook her head, thinking, "No way, that would be too strange. Maybe I'm just tired and stressed from work?" But then she saw how faintly Lily's name was scribbled on the inside of the box, and she felt a chill run down her spine. She tried to rationalize it by telling herself, "It must have been there when I got home," but the image of someone else handling the teddy bear lingered in her mind, making her question whether she really did leave it there. It seemed almost... intentional. She couldn't shake off the feeling that something was off, even though deep down, she knew it was just her tired brain playing tricks on her.

Triggering Event: An elderly man, his fingers trembling slightly as they hover over the keyboard, watches his neighbor's grandson teach him how to video call. The boy laughs, saying, "Grandpa, you should see your face when you hear Mom's voice."
Generated Assessment: You know what would be nice? If I had a grandchild like that. They're so lucky to have parents who are kind and responsible. Their childhood must be amazing. They don't need to worry
